continent.name: Anger
continent.desc: We are blocked in our progress or goal.
continent.desc_mobile: The movement of this shape reflects how anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives. Tap on the shape to learn more about the universal nature of anger.

states.name: Annoyance
states.desc: Very mild anger.
states.desc_mobile: Very mild anger.

states.name: Frustration
states.desc: A response to failure to overcome an obstacle despite repeated attempts.
states.desc_mobile: A response to failure to overcome an obstacle despite repeated attempts.

states.name: Argumentativeness
states.desc: An inclination to prolong disagreements.
states.desc_mobile: An inclination to prolong disagreements.

states.name: Bitterness
states.desc: Disappointment that no one wanted to settle a problem.
states.desc_mobile: Disappointment that no one wanted to settle a problem.

states.name: Exasperation
states.desc: A loss of patience at repeated failures to settle a problem.
states.desc_mobile: A loss of patience at repeated failures to settle a problem.

states.name: Vengefulness
states.desc: A desire for retaliation.
states.desc_mobile: A desire for retaliation.

states.name: Fury
states.desc: Intense anger.
states.desc_mobile: Intense anger.

actions.name: Quarrel
actions.desc: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.
actions.desc_mobile: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.

actions.name: Insult
actions.desc: Disparage the other person in an offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.
actions.desc_mobile: Disparage the other person in an offensive or hurtful way that is likely to escalate the conflict rather than resolve it.

actions.name: Undermine
actions.desc: Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.
actions.desc_mobile: Take action to make someone or something weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.

actions.name: Dispute
actions.desc: Disagree in a manner that may escalate an argument.
actions.desc_mobile: Disagree in a manner that may escalate an argument.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.
actions.desc_mobile: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.

actions.name: Use physical force
actions.desc: Harm or constrain someone, an action that may be deliberately chosen or the result of a loss of control over how one acts.
actions.desc_mobile: Harm or constrain someone, an action that may be deliberately chosen or the result of a loss of control over how one acts.

actions.name: Suppress
actions.desc: Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.
actions.desc_mobile: Try to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.

actions.name: Simmer/brood
actions.desc: Act in a way that makes clear that angry actions are building or being contemplated.
actions.desc_mobile: Act in a way that makes clear that angry actions are building or being contemplated.

actions.name: Be passive-aggressive
actions.desc: Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.
actions.desc_mobile: Take indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.

triggers.name: Interference with locomotion
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Interference with action or locomotion are examples.

triggers.name: Interference with action
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Being wrongfully accused or put down by an authority figure are examples.

triggers.name: Being put down by an authority figure
triggers.name_mobile: Being put down by an authority figure

moods.name: Irritable
moods.desc: A readiness, a need to become angry. Filtering perceptions to see provocations not noticed when not irritable.
moods.desc_mobile: A readiness, a need to become angry. Filtering perceptions to see provocations not noticed when not irritable.

continent.name: Fear
continent.desc: We are threatened to our safety or wellbeing.
continent.desc_mobile: The movement of this shape reflects how anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives. Tap on the shape to learn more about the universal nature of fear.

states.name: Trepidation
states.desc: Anticipation of the possibility of danger.
states.desc_mobile: Anticipation of the possibility of danger.

states.name: Anxiety
states.desc: Inability to cope with an anticipated or actual threat.
states.desc_mobile: Inability to cope with an anticipated or actual threat.

states.name: Nervousness
states.desc: Uncertainty as to whether there is a danger.
states.desc_mobile: Uncertainty as to whether there is a danger.

states.name: Dread
states.desc: Anticipation of severe danger.
states.desc_mobile: Anticipation of severe danger.

states.name: Desperation
states.desc: A response to the inability to reduce danger.
states.desc_mobile: A response to the inability to reduce danger.

states.name: Panic
states.desc: A consequence of desperation.
states.desc_mobile: A consequence of desperation.

states.name: Horror
states.desc: A mixture of fear and disgust.
states.desc_mobile: A mixture of fear and disgust.

states.name: Terror
states.desc: Maximum fear.
states.desc_mobile: Maximum fear.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the fear.
actions.desc_mobile: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the fear.

actions.name: Hesitate
actions.desc: Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.
actions.desc_mobile: Hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.

actions.name: Freeze
actions.desc: Become incapable of acting or speaking.
actions.desc_mobile: Become incapable of acting or speaking.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.
actions.desc_mobile: Lose control of how one speaks; speak in a loud volume and, when screaming, in a higher pitch.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.
actions.desc_mobile: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Worry
actions.desc: Anticipate the possibility of harm.
actions.desc_mobile: Anticipate the possibility of harm.

triggers.name: Imminent bodily impact
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Snake-like shapes and sudden loss of gravity are examples.

triggers.name: Sudden loss of gravity
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Public speaking, thunder, and the threat of losing one’s job are examples.

moods.name: Apprehensive
moods.desc: Expecting harm but not knowing how to avoid it. Perceiving threats when they are not there, or magnifying the seriousness of a threat.
moods.desc_mobile: Expecting harm but not knowing how to avoid it. Perceiving threats when they are not there, or magnifying the seriousness of a threat.

continent.name: Disgust
continent.desc: We are facing something toxic or otherwise unpleasing.
continent.desc_mobile: The movement of this shape reflects how anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives. Tap on the shape to learn more about the universal nature of disgust.

states.name: Dislike
states.desc: The mildest form of disgust.
states.desc_mobile: The mildest form of disgust.

states.name: Aversion
states.desc: A desire to avoid something disgusting.
states.desc_mobile: A desire to avoid something disgusting.

states.name: Distaste
states.desc: Response to a bad taste or smell; can also be metaphorical.
states.desc_mobile: Response to a bad taste or smell; can also be metaphorical.

states.name: Repugnance
states.desc: Repulsion to something literally or figuratively toxic.
states.desc_mobile: Repulsion to something literally or figuratively toxic.

states.name: Revulsion
states.desc: Very intense disgust.
states.desc_mobile: Very intense disgust.

states.name: Abhorrence
states.desc: Extreme repulsion.
states.desc_mobile: Extreme repulsion.

states.name: Loathing
states.desc: Intense disgust focused on a person.
states.desc_mobile: Intense disgust focused on a person.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the disgust.
actions.desc_mobile: Either physically stay away from someone or something, or internally keep one’s mind away from what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Vomit
actions.desc: Expel material from the stomach via the mouth; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.
actions.desc_mobile: Expel material from the stomach via the mouth; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.

actions.name: Dehumanize
actions.desc: Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.
actions.desc_mobile: Treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; deprive someone of human qualities, personality or spirit.

triggers.name: Anything coming out of the body
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Anything in decay or coming out of the body are examples.

triggers.name: Rotting or decay
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Unfamiliar religious customs and eating insects or raw meat are examples.

triggers.name: Fans of an opposing sports team
triggers.name_mobile: Fans of an opposing sports team

moods.name: Sour
moods.desc: Disgust can occur as a mood, a generalized feeling of repugnance.
moods.desc_mobile: Disgust can occur as a mood, a generalized feeling of repugnance.

continent.name: Sadness
continent.desc: We are experiencing loss of something valuable.
continent.desc_mobile: The movement of this shape reflects how anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives. Tap on the shape to learn more about the universal nature of sadness.

states.name: Disappointment
states.desc: A feeling that expectations are not being met.
states.desc_mobile: A feeling that expectations are not being met.

states.name: Resignation
states.desc: Acceptance that nothing can be done.
states.desc_mobile: Acceptance that nothing can be done.

states.name: Distraughtness
states.desc: Agitated sadness.
states.desc_mobile: Agitated sadness.

states.name: Discouragement
states.desc: A feeling that there is no way to cope.
states.desc_mobile: A feeling that there is no way to cope.

states.name: Helplessness
states.desc: Realization of the inability to prevent or cope with loss.
states.desc_mobile: Realization of the inability to prevent or cope with loss.

states.name: Misery
states.desc: Anguished sadness, usually prolonged.
states.desc_mobile: Anguished sadness, usually prolonged.

states.name: Hopelessness
states.desc: A feeling that nothing good is to come.
states.desc_mobile: A feeling that nothing good is to come.

states.name: Grief
states.desc: Anguished sadness over the loss of a loved one.
states.desc_mobile: Anguished sadness over the loss of a loved one.

states.name: Despair
states.desc: Resigned anguish.
states.desc_mobile: Resigned anguish.

states.name: Sorrow
states.desc: Sadness over a loss.
states.desc_mobile: Sadness over a loss.

states.name: Anguish
states.desc: Intense agitated sadness.
states.desc_mobile: Intense agitated sadness.

actions.name: Seek comfort
actions.desc: Seek help or support from others.
actions.desc_mobile: Seek help or support from others.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the sadness.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the sadness.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.
actions.desc_mobile: Repetitively think about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Mourn
actions.desc: Focus on the loss.
actions.desc_mobile: Focus on the loss.

actions.name: Protest
actions.desc: Complain about the loss, knowing that the complaint will not recover what was lost.
actions.desc_mobile: Complain about the loss, knowing that the complaint will not recover what was lost.

actions.name: Feel ashamed
actions.desc: Feel the need to hide how one feels about what or who is lost.
actions.desc_mobile: Feel the need to hide how one feels about what or who is lost.

triggers.name: Being rejected by someone important
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Losing or being rejected by a loved one are examples.

triggers.name: Losing a loved one
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Feeling left out or experiencing a perceived loss of status are examples.

triggers.name: Not being invited to a party
triggers.name_mobile: Not being invited to a party

moods.name: Dysphoria (or feeling blue)
moods.desc: Feelings of resignation, discouragement or disappointment that endure. Anguish does not transform into a mood.
moods.desc_mobile: Feelings of resignation, discouragement or disappointment that endure. Anguish does not transform into a mood.

continent.name: Enjoyment
continent.desc: We are pleased with our experience.
continent.desc_mobile: The movement of this shape reflects how anger varies in strength and frequency in our lives. Tap on the shape to learn more about the universal nature of enjoyment.

states.name: Sensory pleasure
states.desc: Enjoyment derived through one of the five physical senses: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment derived through one of the five physical senses: sight, sound, touch, taste and smell.

states.name: Rejoicing
states.desc: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness and compassion. Also called elevation.
states.desc_mobile: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness and compassion. Also called elevation.

states.name: Amusement
states.desc: Light, playful feelings of enjoyment and good humor.
states.desc_mobile: Light, playful feelings of enjoyment and good humor.

states.name: Relief
states.desc: When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.
states.desc_mobile: When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.

states.name: Compassion/joy
states.desc: Enjoyment felt when you act to relieve another person’s suffering.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment felt when you act to relieve another person’s suffering.

states.name: Schadenfreude
states.desc: Enjoyment of the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.
states.desc_mobile: Enjoyment of the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.

states.name: Fiero
states.desc: An Italian word that describes the enjoyment felt when you have met a challenge that stretched your capabilities.
states.desc_mobile: An Italian word that describes the enjoyment felt when you have met a challenge that stretched your capabilities.

states.name: Naches
states.desc: A Yiddish word for feelings of pride in the accomplishments, or sometimes just the existence, of your actual offspring or mentored offspring. Crucial for motivating the nurture of infants and children.
states.desc_mobile: A Yiddish word for feelings of pride in the accomplishments, or sometimes just the existence, of your actual offspring or mentored offspring. Crucial for motivating the nurture of infants and children.

states.name: Pride
states.desc: A desire for others to know the pleasure you feel in your own accomplishments or the accomplishments of someone you either nurtured directly or identify with.
states.desc_mobile: A desire for others to know the pleasure you feel in your own accomplishments or the accomplishments of someone you either nurtured directly or identify with.

states.name: Wonder
states.desc: An experience of something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing or hard to believe.
states.desc_mobile: An experience of something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing or hard to believe.

states.name: Peace
states.desc: An experience of ease and contenment.
states.desc_mobile: An experience of ease and contenment.

states.name: Excitement
states.desc: Energy that, unlike other enjoyable emotions, is rarely felt slightly, but ranges from mid to high in intesnity. May merge with any of the emotions, generating a very active form of that emotion.
states.desc_mobile: Energy that, unlike other enjoyable emotions, is rarely felt slightly, but ranges from mid to high in intesnity. May merge with any of the emotions, generating a very active form of that emotion.

states.name: Ecstasy
states.desc: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.
states.desc_mobile: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is causing the enjoyment.
actions.desc_mobile: Physically or mentally leave the scene of what is causing the enjoyment.

actions.name: Seek more
actions.desc: Attempt to increase the enjoyable feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Attempt to increase the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Maintain
actions.desc: Continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Gloat
actions.desc: Enjoy others’ envy of your state of enjoyment.
actions.desc_mobile: Enjoy others’ envy of your state of enjoyment.

actions.name: Exclaim
actions.desc: Vocally express enjoyment to others.
actions.desc_mobile: Vocally express enjoyment to others.

actions.name: Engage/connect
actions.desc: Desire connection and engagement with others to share in feelings of enjoyment.
actions.desc_mobile: Desire connection and engagement with others to share in feelings of enjoyment.

actions.name: Savor
actions.desc: Relish the experience of good feelings about physical and psychological experiences.
actions.desc_mobile: Relish the experience of good feelings about physical and psychological experiences.

actions.name: Indulge
actions.desc: Excessively engage in the enjoyable feelings.
actions.desc_mobile: Excessively engage in the enjoyable feelings.

triggers.name: Sensory experience of nature
triggers.desc_mobile: Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone, and affect us more intensely than learned triggers. Social interaction and experiencing nature are examples.

triggers.name: Helping others
triggers.desc_mobile: Some triggers can be learned from personal or shared cultural experiences. Spending time with family or visiting places from one’s youth are examples.

moods.name: Elation
moods.desc: Generalized, non-specific, non-triggered good feeling, lasting hours.
moods.desc_mobile: Generalized, non-specific, non-triggered good feeling, lasting hours.

intro.header: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
intro.header_mobile: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
intro.body_mobile:
This atlas was inspired by a series of conversations between the Dalai Lama and Dr. Paul Ekman about the science of emotion.

The following collection of maps provide an opportunity to explore the landscape of emotions, where they come from and the effects they can have.

steps.header: Welcome to the Atlas of Emotions
steps.body:
This atlas was inspired by a series of conversations between the Dalai Lama and Paul Ekman about the science of emotions. With the help of Stamen Design and Paul’s daughter, Dr. Eve Ekman, this tool was created to be a visual journey through the world of emotions.

Learn more about the work of Paul Ekman at www.paulekman.com.
steps.caption: His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Dr. Paul Ekman and Dr. Eve Ekman

steps.body: In June 2014, Paul Ekman sent a survey to 248 of the most active emotion researchers in the world to establish the consensus that provided the scientific basis for this atlas.
steps.caption: of those who responded agree that there are Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where we live or how we were raised, have in common.

steps.body: This collection of maps is an opportunity for you to explore the landscape of emotions, where they come from, and the effects they can have. Click on shapes to learn about them. Use the arrows and scrollbar to navigate to other pages.

continents.body: Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. The movement of the shapes reflects how the emotions vary in strength and frequency in our lives. Select an emotion to learn more.
continents.body_mobile: Most emotions researchers agree on these five Universal Emotions: emotions that all humans, no matter where or how we were raised, have in common. Tap on an emotion to start exploring.

states.body: LHAMO can be felt mildly, extremely, or somewhere in between. Select a shape to learn about a few of the states that we can experience.
states.body_mobile: LHAMO can be felt mildly, extremely, or somewhere in between. Tap and drag across the shapes above to learn about a few of the states that we can experience.

actions.body: We respond to emotional states with our actions. Select a state to learn about the possible actions resulting from LHAMO. Then click on an action to learn more.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is CONSTRUCTIVE. It enables collaboration.
qualities.body_mobile: We respond to emotional states with our actions. Tap and drag across the shapes to learn about the possible actions resulting from LHAMO.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is AMBIGUOUS. It may either enable or inhibit collaboration.
qualities.body_mobile: In this state, this action is AMBIGUOUS. It may either enable or inhibit collaboration.

qualities.body: In this state, this action is DESTRUCTIVE. It inhibits collaboration.
qualities.body_mobile: In this state, this action is DESTRUCTIVE. It inhibits collaboration.

triggers.body: A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Select the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.

steps.body: Some triggers are hardwired and universal for everyone, other triggers are learned from the world around us and our individual experience.
steps.body_mobile: A trigger is something around us or in our own minds that causes us to feel an emotion. Tap on the labels to learn about triggering LHAMO.

steps.body: Past personal experience determines whether or not a learned trigger makes us feel emotional. Universal triggers break through regardless.
steps.body_mobile: Past personal experience determines whether or not a learned trigger makes us feel emotional. Universal triggers break through regardless.

steps.body: Emotion is our automatic response to being triggered. The state of emotion we feel and the actions we take often happen without our realizing why.
steps.body_mobile: Emotion is our automatic response to being triggered. The state of emotion we feel and the actions we take often happen without our realizing why.

steps.body: This is an example of a universal trigger. Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.
steps.body_mobile: This is an example of a universal trigger. Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.

steps.body: This is an example of a learned trigger. Learned triggers can be informed by our culture, stemming from widely shared experiences and norms, or personal, created from important and impactful individual experiences.
steps.body_mobile: This is an example of a learned trigger. Learned triggers can be informed by our culture, stemming from widely shared experiences and norms, or personal, created from important and impactful individual experiences.

moods.body: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Select the shape to learn more.
moods.body_mobile: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause us to feel the related emotion repeatedly without any clear trigger. Tap on the shape to learn more.

calm.body: A calm, balanced frame of mind helps us understand our changing emotions. We can reach calmness through developing an awareness of what triggers our emotions, how we experience our states of emotions and what actions are constructive. Calmness ideally is our baseline in which emotions arise when triggered and then recede .

secondary.body: To learn more about emotions, click on “More Information” in the bottom right corner.
secondary.body_mobile: A calm, balanced frame of mind helps us understand our changing emotions. We can reach calmness through developing an awareness of what triggers our emotions, how we experience our states of emotions and what actions are constructive. Calmness ideally is our baseline in which emotions arise when triggered and then recede .
